questions.text: A 76-year-old woman comes to the physician for evaluation of a 3-month history of vulvar itching and pain. She was diagnosed with lichen sclerosus 4 years ago. She has smoked 1 pack of cigarettes daily for 35 years. Physical examination shows a 2.5-cm nodular, ulcerative lesion on the vaginal introitus and left labia minora with surrounding erythema. Punch biopsy shows squamous cell carcinoma. A CT scan of the chest, abdomen, and pelvis shows enlarged lymph nodes concerning for metastatic disease. Which of the following lymph node regions is the most likely primary site of metastasis?
questions.solution:
A) CORRECT:

The superficial inguinal nodes are the primary lymphatic draining site for the distal vagina and vulva. The path of lymphatic drainage then continues via the deep inguinal to the pelvic and external iliac lymph nodes, and finally to the paraaortic lymph nodes. This pathway is different from all other cancers of the female reproductive tract.

B) INCORRECT:

The para-aortic lymph nodes are the primary draining site for the ovaries. The lymphatic fluid follows the gonadal arteries back to the abdominal aorta, near the site of early gonadal development and differentiation of the mesonephros. The para-aortic lymph nodes do not drain the distal vagina and vulva.

C) INCORRECT:

The inferior mesenteric lymph nodes are the primary draining site for the colon starting from the splenic flexure to the upper rectum. They do not commonly drain the genital tract.

D) INCORRECT:

The external iliac lymph nodes are the primary draining site for the body of the uterus as well as the superior bladder. While they also receive lymph from the distal vagina and vulva at some point, they are not the first site of lymphatic drainage for these organs.

E) INCORRECT:

The internal iliac lymph nodes are the primary draining site for the middle third of the vagina as well as the cervix. They do not drain the distal vagina and vulva. The internal iliac nodes also drain the bladder and the lower rectum to the anal canal (above pectinate line).

F) INCORRECT:

The deep inguinal lymph nodes are located medial to the femoral vein. Although lymphatic fluid from the distal vagina and vulva may collect in these lymph nodes, they are neither the most direct nor the primary site of lymphatic drainage from these organs. Metastatic cancer from these organs is possible in this lymph node basin but would not be the most likely location for metastasis.
questions.hint: This lymph node region would also be the first site of metastasis in penile cancer.

questions.text: Thirty minutes after normal vaginal delivery of twins, a 35-year-old woman, gravida 5, para 4, has heavy vaginal bleeding with clots. Physical examination shows a soft, enlarged, and boggy uterus. Despite bimanual uterine massage, administration of uterotonic drugs, and placement of an intrauterine balloon for tamponade, the bleeding continues. A hysterectomy is performed. Vessels running through which of the following structures must be ligated during the surgery to achieve hemostasis?
questions.solution:
A) INCORRECT:

The suspensory ligament of the ovary (infundibulopelvic ligament) attaches the ovary to the lateral pelvic wall. The ovarian vessels travel through this ligament to supply the ovaries and the upper part of the uterus. To achieve rapid hemostasis, the ligament containing the uterine arteries (main blood supply to the uterus) should first be ligated. Because this patient is young, the ovarian vessels and ovaries should ideally be preserved during hysterectomy to avoid premature menopause.

B) INCORRECT:

The uterosacral ligaments are avascular fibrous bands that connect the cervix to the sacrum, thereby providing mechanical support to the uterus. Although the uterosacral ligaments will be divided during the course of a hysterectomy, this will not contribute to achieving hemostasis in this patient.

C) CORRECT:

The cardinal ligament (transverse cervical ligament) connects the cervix with the lateral pelvic wall, providing support to the uterus. It contains the uterine artery, which is the main blood supply of the uterus. Ligation of the uterine vessels is imperative to perform hysterectomy and obtain hemostasis in this patient. During hysterectomy, the ureters are at increased risk for injury due to their proximity to the cardinal ligament.

Uterine atony (as evidenced by the soft, boggy uterus in this patient) is the most common cause of postpartum hemorrhage and occurs when the myometrial fibers of the uterus fail to fully contract and compress the uteroplacental vasculature (branches of the uterine artery) after placental delivery. Patients with a history of multiple pregnancies are at increased risk.
Image Description:

The uterus is connected to the pelvic walls by ligaments and peritoneal folds. These structures provide support and allow for flexible movement of the uterus between the urinary bladder and the rectum, especially during pregnancy.

- The round ligament extends from the lateral horn of the uterus to the lateral pelvic wall and via the inguinal canal to the labia majora.
- The largest ligament is the broad ligament of the uterus, a peritoneal fold that connects the uterus to the lateral pelvic wall. The broad ligament can be divided into the mesosalpinx, the mesovarium, and the mesometrium.
- The ovaries are suspended from the uterus by the ovarian ligament and from the lateral pelvic wall by the suspensory (infundibulopelvic) ligament of the ovary.
- The cardinal ligament encloses the uterine artery and vein and connects the cervix with the lateral pelvic wall.
- The uterosacral ligament connects the cervix to the sacrum.

D) INCORRECT:

The round ligament connects the uterine fundus to the labia majora. It contains the Sampson artery, which is a small, insignificant vessel that anastomoses with the uterine and ovarian arteries. Although the round ligaments would be ligated during a hysterectomy, their ligation will not contribute to achieving hemostasis in this patient.

E) INCORRECT:

The ovarian ligament connects the uterus and ovaries. The ovarian branch of the uterine artery runs along the lower border of the ovarian ligament, but this vessel has no role in postpartum hemorrhage.
questions.hint: The uterine artery, a branch of the internal iliac artery, supplies blood to the uterus. It runs through a structure located at the base of the broad ligament of the uterus.

questions.text: An investigator is studying cellular regeneration of epithelial cells. She has obtained a tissue sample from a normal thyroid gland for histopathologic examination. It shows follicles lined by a single layer of cube-like cells with large central nuclei. Which of the following parts of the female reproductive tract is also lined by this type of epithelium?
questions.solution:
A) CORRECT:

The epithelium of the ovaries, also known as the female germinal epithelium, is a simple cuboidal epithelium. It covers the ovaries and aids in ovarian follicular development and oocyte release by proliferating both to accommodate follicular growth and to cover defects left by oocyte release. Female germinal epithelium was previously thought to give rise to high-grade serous cystadenocarcinoma, the most common and aggressive type of ovarian cancer. However, recent research has shown that this type of cancer is most likely derived from fallopian tube epithelium.
Image Description:

Microscopic image of the ovary (H&E stain, ca. 450x magnification)

The ovary is completely surrounded by cubic to columnar epithelium (peritoneal epithelium, black arrow).
Underneath is the tunica albuginea (black line), a thin layer of connective tissue.
Beneath is the cortex ovari, which consists of spinocellular connective tissue, in which the numerous ovarian follicles in their different stages of development are embedded. Most of them are primordial follicles (some overlayed in green) in diktyotän, a dormant stage. In the two marked primordial follicles, condensed chromosomes are seen as basophile “lumps”, which is typical for this state.
Ther is a primary follicle (dashed outline) on the left, clearly distinguishable by the single layer of cubic epithelial cells.
On the lower edge are luteinized theca cells (white arrows), which are presumably part of a corpus luteum, which is not completely on the picture.

B) INCORRECT:

The epithelium of the vagina is a nonkeratinized stratified squamous epithelium, not simple cuboidal epithelium. The function of stratified squamous epithelium throughout the body (e.g., vagina, anal canal, esophagus, cornea) is to protect against both mechanical force and pathogens. The majority of all vaginal cancers are squamous cell carcinomas, derived from vaginal epithelium, oftentimes following infection with high-risk strains of HPV. However, the epithelium described here, does not line the vagina.
Image Description:

Photomicrograph of vaginal tissue (azan trichrome stain; ~150x magnification)

This image shows the eosinophilic, stratified, nonkeratinized, squamous epithelium of the vagina. The epithelial cells accumulate glycogen in granules. In the desquamated cells, the glycogen is broken down to lactic acid by natural vaginal flora.

The lamina propria is rich in collagen fibres that stain blue. The white, seemingly empty areas are most likely vessels running through the lamina propria.

Characteristically, there are no mucous glands.

C) INCORRECT:

The epithelium of the endometrium is simple columnar epithelium that has long straight glands during the proliferative phase and coiled glands during the secretory phase of the menstrual cycle. The majority of endometrial cancers are endometroid carcinomas, derived from endometrial epithelium, usually preceded by endometrial hyperplasia. However, the epithelium described here is not found in the endometrium.
Image Description:

Photomicrograph of uterine tissue (H&E stain; 100x magnification)

Tissue layers (from bottom left to top right and from inside out):
– Myometrium (light purple)
– Endometrium (dark purple) with endometrial glands (white)

During the beginning of the proliferative phase, the endometrial glands are still relatively straight, unlike the cork-screw shape they adopt during the late proliferative and the luteal phase.

Click on the Smartzoom button to view the entire specimen through a virtual microscope.

D) INCORRECT:

The fallopian tubes are lined with ciliated simple columnar epithelium, not simple cuboidal epithelium. The cilia function to propel egg cells towards the tubal ampulla and uterus. However, the epithelium described in here is not found in the fallopian tubes.
Image Description:

Photomicrograph of a section of the fallopian tube (H&E stain, approx. 650x magnification)

The fallopian tube has a single-layered epithelium consisting of two cell types. Ciliated cells appear wide and light (red overlay), they move the ovum away from the ovary and towards the uterus. Peg cells appear darker and narrower (white outline), they secrete nutrients for the ovum.

E) INCORRECT:

The epithelium of the vulva is a keratinized stratified squamous epithelium, not simple cuboidal epithelium. The function of keratinized stratified squamous epithelium is to protect against mechanical force, pathogens, and, because of the keratinized layer, desiccation. This type of epithelium covers the skin. The vast majority of all vulvar cancers are squamous cell carcinomas, derived from vulvar epithelium, oftentimes following infection with high-risk strains of HPV. However, the epithelium described here is not found in the vulva.
Image Description:

Photomicrograph of a vulvar tissue sample (H&E stain; 200× magnification)

The epidermis (green overlay) and dermis (yellow overlay) are both visible. Below the typical keratinized stratified squamous epithelium, there is a slightly increased amount of lymphocytes in the dermis (most likely subclinical inflammation; examples indicated by arrows).

F) INCORRECT:

The cervix consists of two parts, the endocervix and the ectocervix. The outer ectocervix is comprised of nonkeratinized stratified squamous epithelium, while the inner endocervix consists of simple columnar epithelium. The junction between the two is called the transformation zone. The transformation zone is the location of the majority of cervical cancers, which are most commonly derived from cervical epithelium following infection with high-risk HPV strains. However, the epithelium described here is not found in the cervix.
Image Description:

Photomicrograph of uterine tissue (H&E Stain)

The uterine cervix is divided into the endocervix (covered with columnar epithelium (yellow overlay), consisting of one layer of mucin-secreting cells) and the ectocervix (covered with non-keratinizing, stratified squamous epithelium (red overlay)). Underneath both types of epithelium, a layer of connective tissue can be found. In between, a transitional area, known as the squamocolumnar junction (black dashed line), is visible. As a result of the constant remodeling process due to uterine growth, cervical enlargement and hormonal status, it is where most precancerous lesions of the cervix are located.

No pathologies are noted.
questions.hint: The epithelium described is simple cuboidal epithelium. The female reproductive organ that is lined with this type of epithelium is derived from coelomic epithelium, which also lines the peritoneum.

questions.text: A 42-year-old woman comes to the physician because of right flank pain that started 3 days following a procedure. Her vital signs are within normal limits. Physical examination shows right costovertebral angle tenderness. An intravenous pyelogram shows a dilated renal pelvis and ureter on the right with a lack of contrast in the lower third of the ureter. This patient most likely recently underwent which of the following procedures?
questions.solution:
A) INCORRECT:

A cesarean section is performed by opening the anterior abdominal wall and making a low transverse incision on the anterior wall of the uterus. Although the ureters are in close proximity to the lateral walls of the uterus in a non-gravid state, they are pushed laterally as the uterus enlarges during pregnancy. This makes them less susceptible to injury during a cesarean section.

B) CORRECT:

The lower third of the ureter (pelvic ureter) lies just below the cardinal ligament, which contains the uterine artery. Because the uterine arteries are ligated during a hysterectomy, the ureters are at risk of being injured. The ureters are also susceptible to injury during ovarian surgeries (e.g., oophorectomy) as they lie below the infundibulopelvic ligament, which contains the ovarian arteries. Although any abdominopelvic surgery is a risk factor for ureteric injuries, hysterectomies are the most frequent cause.

C) INCORRECT:

A Foley catheter is usually inserted into the bladder through the urethra (in rare cases through the anterior abdominal wall in suprapubic catheterization) and can therefore potentially damage the urethral mucosa (not the ureter), resulting in a urethral stricture as it heals. Instrumentation of the ureter (e.g., during ureteroscopy) is a risk factor for ureteric stricture, but urethral catheterization with a Foley catheter is not.

D) INCORRECT:

An inguinal hernia protrudes either through the deep inguinal ring (indirect inguinal hernia) or posterior wall of the inguinal canal (direct inguinal hernia). The contents of an inguinal hernia usually consist of intraperitoneal structures, most commonly omentum or bowel. In large hernias, the bladder may also be involved. The ureter is rarely involved in inguinal hernias and is thus rarely injured during a hernia repair.

E) INCORRECT:

The appendix lies in the right lower quadrant of the abdomen, in close proximity to the cecum, ileum, and psoas and obturator muscles. The free portion of the appendix may assume a variety of positions, and in the pelvic position, lies in close proximity to the right ureter. However, the retrocecal position is much more common and the ureter is rarely injured during an appendectomy. A different procedure is more likely to have resulted in this patient's symptoms.
questions.hint: The intravenous pyelogram results describe a ureteral stricture located close to a structure that is commonly ligated in this procedure.

questions.text: A 36-year-old woman, gravida 2, para 2, comes to the emergency department because of sudden-onset, severe right flank pain. She was in her aerobics class when the pain started but denies any trauma to the region. She has a history of recurrent ovarian cysts. Menses occur regularly at 28-day intervals. Her temperature is 37.1°C (99.3°F). Abdominal examination shows tenderness in the right lower quadrant with guarding. Pelvic ultrasound shows a large simple cyst on the right ovary. Right ovarian artery flow is detectable on Doppler, but there is no flow detected in the right ovarian vein. Which of the following ligaments is most likely to have been involved?
questions.solution:
A) INCORRECT:

The broad ligament is a fold of peritoneum that is divided into three parts: mesosalpinx, mesometrium, and mesovarium. It connects the lateral uterus, fallopian tubes, and ovaries with the lateral pelvic wall. Although it is in close relation to the ovaries, the ligament does not contain the ovarian vessels and is not primarily affected during ovarian torsion.

B) INCORRECT:

The round ligament of the uterus connects the labia majora to the uterine horns. It is a remnant of the gubernaculum and does not contain any vessels. The ligament's main function is to maintain anteversion of the uterus in the pelvic cavity. It is not affected during ovarian torsion.

C) INCORRECT:

The ovarian ligament is an embryonic remnant of the gubernaculum and connects the medial pole of the ovary to the uterine horns. It contains the ovarian branches of the uterine vessels, not the ovarian vessels themselves, and is not primarily affected by ovarian torsion.

D) INCORRECT:

The cardinal ligament connects the cervix to the lateral walls of the pelvis. It carries the uterine vessels and the ureter, not the ovarian vessels. Furthermore, the cardinal ligament is not affected during ovarian torsion.

E) CORRECT:

The infundibulopelvic ligament (suspensory ligament of the ovary) is a fold of peritoneum that connects the ovaries to the lateral walls of the pelvis. It carries the ovarian artery, vein, nerves, and lymphatics, and is affected during ovarian torsion, which requires surgical management. If the ovary is deemed nonviable, the infundibulopelvic ligament is ligated during oophorectomy. During this procedure, care must be taken not to damage the ureter, which is located directly posterior to the ligament in the retroperitoneum.
Image Description:

In ovarian torsion, the ovary twists around the adnexal ligaments, resulting in compression of the ovarian veins and lymphatics, consequently causing venous congestion and edema. The most important risk factor is ovarian enlargement, which can occur (e.g., due to ovarian cysts).
questions.hint: This patient's sudden onset of severe right flank pain, history of recurrent ovarian cysts, and lack of ovarian venous flow on Doppler are consistent with ovarian torsion.

questions.text: A 33-year-old woman comes to the emergency department because of a 1-hour history of severe pelvic pain and nausea. She was diagnosed with a follicular cyst in the left ovary 3 months ago. The cyst was found incidentally during a fertility evaluation. A pelvic ultrasound with Doppler flow shows an enlarged, edematous left ovary with no blood flow. Laparoscopic evaluation shows necrosis of the left ovary, and a left oophorectomy is performed. During the procedure, blunt dissection of the left infundibulopelvic ligament is performed. Which of the following structures is most at risk of injury during this step of the surgery?
questions.solution:
A) CORRECT:

The ureters pass through the pelvic brim within the ureteric fold, which lies posterior and medial, and in close proximity, to the infundibulopelvic ligament. Any dissection of the infundibulopelvic ligament should be performed with great care because of the risk of iatrogenic ureteral injury. Patients with fibrosis or endometriosis are at especially high risk of iatrogenic ureter injury during this surgical step.

Because of their long retroperitoneal course, the ureters are at risk of injury during lower abdominal procedures, such as gonadal vessel ligation, uterine vessel ligation, pelvic dissection, and dissection at the ureterovesical junction.
Image Description:

The uterus is connected to the pelvic walls by ligaments and peritoneal folds. These structures provide support and allow for flexible movement of the uterus between the urinary bladder and the rectum, especially during pregnancy.

- The round ligament extends from the lateral horn of the uterus to the lateral pelvic wall and via the inguinal canal to the labia majora.
- The largest ligament is the broad ligament of the uterus, a peritoneal fold that connects the uterus to the lateral pelvic wall. The broad ligament can be divided into the mesosalpinx, the mesovarium, and the mesometrium.
- The ovaries are suspended from the uterus by the ovarian ligament and from the lateral pelvic wall by the suspensory (infundibulopelvic) ligament of the ovary.
- The cardinal ligament encloses the uterine artery and vein and connects the cervix with the lateral pelvic wall.
- The uterosacral ligament connects the cervix to the sacrum.

B) INCORRECT:

The bladder trigone is located at the base of the bladder, caudal to the infundibulopelvic ligament. This portion of the bladder is, therefore, unlikely to be injured during this step of the procedure.

C) INCORRECT:

The uterosacral ligament connects the cervix to the sacrum and provides mechanical support to the uterus. This ligament is located caudal to the infundibulopelvic ligament and is, therefore, unlikely to be injured during this step of the procedure.

D) INCORRECT:

The kidneys are located retroperitoneally, approximately at the T12–L3 vertebral levels. They are not connected to, nor in the immediate vicinity of, the infundibulopelvic ligament and are, therefore, unlikely to be injured during this step of the procedure.

E) INCORRECT:

The cervical os acts as a passage between the uterus and the vagina. This structure has two major components: an internal cervical os (endocervix) and an external cervical os (ectocervix). The cervical os is located caudal to the infundibulopelvic ligament and is, therefore, unlikely to be injured during this step of the procedure.

F) INCORRECT:

The uterine artery (and vein) is contained within the cardinal ligament, which forms the inferior portion of the broad ligament. The uterine artery is located caudal to the infundibulopelvic ligament and is, therefore, unlikely to be injured during this step of the procedure.
Image Description:

The arterial supply of the female reproductive organs mainly comes from branches of the uterine artery. The uterine artery arises from the internal iliac artery and crosses the ureter anteriorly in the broad ligament at the level of the cervix. The ovary and fallopian tubes are supplied by branches of the ovarian artery that arise from the abdominal aorta and anastomose with the ovarian branches of the uterine artery.

Note that the vessels adjacent to the uterus are tortuous to accommodate the massive growth of the uterus during pregnancy.
questions.hint: This structure passes posterior to the infundibulopelvic ligament at the level of the pelvic brim.

questions.text: A 67-year-old woman is brought to the emergency department because of severe abdominal pain for 1 hour. She has hypertension and coronary heart disease. She has smoked 2 packs of cigarettes daily for 30 years. Her pulse is 140/min and blood pressure is 89/58 mm Hg. Physical examination shows a pulsatile abdominal mass. A CT scan of the abdomen shows a ruptured abdominal aortic aneurysm. The patient is taken to the operating room for emergency open surgery. During the procedure, an artery that branches off from the aorta, just below the renal arteries, at the level of the L2 vertebra is damaged. The arterial supply to which of the following structures is most likely to be impaired by the intraoperative vascular damage?
questions.solution:
A) INCORRECT:

The ascending colon is supplied mostly by the right colic artery, which branches off from the superior mesenteric artery. The superior mesenteric artery is a direct branch of the abdominal aorta and arises suprarenally at the level of the L1 vertebra. The artery in question, however, is located at the level of the L2 vertebra.
Image Description:

The mesenteric arteries and their branches supply parts of the pancreas, the jejunum, the ileum, the cecum, the vermiform appendix, the colon, and the rectum. The superior mesenteric artery supplies the intestine up to the transverse colon, while the inferior mesenteric artery supplies the descending colon, the sigmoid colon, and the upper rectum.

Proximal to the Cannon point, parasympathetic innervation is provided by the vagus nerve. Distal to that point, the pelvic splanchnic nerves provide innervation.

B) INCORRECT:

The liver receives 40% of its blood supply from the hepatic artery proper, a branch of the common hepatic artery, which is, in turn, a branch of the celiac trunk of the abdominal aorta. The celiac trunk arises suprarenally at the level of the T12 vertebra. The injured artery in this patient, however, arises at the level of the L2 vertebra.
Image Description:

The celiac trunk and its three major branches: the left gastric artery, the splenic artery, and the common hepatic artery

C) CORRECT:

Both ovarian arteries branch off directly from the abdominal aorta just below the renal arteries at the level of the L2 vertebra. An injury to one of the ovarian arteries, as seen here, would significantly deprive the respective ovary of its arterial blood supply. The ovarian artery, which forms an anastomosis with the uterine artery, also supplies the lateral two-thirds of the fallopian tube as well as the proximal part of the uterus.

D) INCORRECT:

The adrenal glands are supplied by three arteries: the superior suprarenal artery (from the inferior phrenic artery), middle suprarenal artery (from the abdominal aorta), and inferior suprarenal artery (from the renal artery). All of these arteries arise between the T12 and the lower border of the L1 vertebrae. The injured artery in this patient, however, arises at the level of the L2 vertebra.
Image Description:

Branches of the abdominal aorta:
- 3 single anterior branches: celiac artery, superior mesenteric artery, and inferior mesenteric artery
- 8 paired lateral branches (right and left): inferior phrenic arteries, middle suprarenal arteries, renal arteries, gonadal (testicular/ovarian) arteries, and 4 pairs of lumbar arteries
- 3 terminal branches: right and left common iliac arteries and the median sacral artery (the latter is not shown in the image)

Tributaries of the inferior vena cava:
- Main confluencing tributaries: right and left common iliac veins and the median sacral vein
- Lateral tributaries: bilateral renal veins, right gonadal vein (the left gonadal vein drains into the left renal vein), right suprarenal vein (the left suprarenal vein drains into the left renal vein), lumbar veins, and inferior phrenic veins
- Anterior tributaries: hepatic veins

Note: As the left renal vein passes in front of the aorta, underneath the superior mesenteric artery, it is susceptible to compression between these structures, known as nutcracker phenomenon.

E) INCORRECT:

The cervix is supplied by the uterine artery, which is a branch of the internal iliac artery. The internal iliac artery branches off in the pelvic region from the common iliac artery, which arises from the abdominal aorta at the level of the L4 vertebra. The artery injured in this patient, however, arises at the level of the L2 vertebra.
Image Description:

The arterial supply of the female reproductive organs mainly comes from branches of the uterine artery. The uterine artery arises from the internal iliac artery and crosses the ureter anteriorly in the broad ligament at the level of the cervix. The ovary and fallopian tubes are supplied by branches of the ovarian artery that arise from the abdominal aorta and anastomose with the ovarian branches of the uterine artery.

Note that the vessels adjacent to the uterus are tortuous to accommodate the massive growth of the uterus during pregnancy.

F) INCORRECT:

The descending colon is supplied mostly by the left colic artery, which branches off from the inferior mesenteric artery. The inferior mesenteric artery is a direct branch of the abdominal aorta and arises at the level of the L3 vertebra. The artery in question, however, is located at the level of the L2 vertebra.
Image Description:

The mesenteric arteries and their branches supply parts of the pancreas, the jejunum, the ileum, the cecum, the vermiform appendix, the colon, and the rectum. The superior mesenteric artery supplies the intestine up to the transverse colon, while the inferior mesenteric artery supplies the descending colon, the sigmoid colon, and the upper rectum.

Proximal to the Cannon point, parasympathetic innervation is provided by the vagus nerve. Distal to that point, the pelvic splanchnic nerves provide innervation.

G) INCORRECT:

The spleen receives its arterial blood supply from the splenic artery, which branches off from the celiac trunk. The celiac trunk, in turn, branches off from the aorta suprarenally at the superior border of the T12 vertebra. The artery in question, however, is located at the level of the L2 vertebra.
Image Description:

Branches arising from the superior pancreaticoduodenal (celiac trunk) and inferior pancreaticoduodenal artery (superior mesenteric artery) supply the pancreatic head and neck. These vessels also supply the duodenum. The dorsal pancreatic artery and the greater pancreatic artery supply the tail of the pancreas. The splenic artery supplies the spleen.
questions.hint: The damaged artery passes through the infundibulopelvic ligament.

questions.text: A 36-year-old woman comes to the emergency department because of sudden-onset, severe right flank pain. She was in her aerobics class when the pain started but denies any trauma to the region. She has a history of recurrent ovarian cysts. Menses occur regularly at 28-day intervals. Her temperature is 37.1°C (99.3°F). Abdominal examination shows tenderness in the right lower quadrant with guarding. Pelvic ultrasound shows a large simple cyst on the right ovary. Right ovarian artery flow is detectable on Doppler, but there is no flow detected in the right ovarian vein. Which of the following ligaments is most likely to have been involved?
questions.solution:
A) INCORRECT:

The broad ligament is a fold of peritoneum that is divided into three parts: mesosalpinx, mesometrium, and mesovarium. It connects the lateral uterus, fallopian tubes, and ovaries with the lateral pelvic wall. Although it is in close relation to the ovaries, the ligament does not contain the ovarian vessels and is not primarily affected during ovarian torsion.

B) INCORRECT:

The round ligament of the uterus connects the labia majora to the uterine horns. It is a remnant of the gubernaculum and does not contain any vessels. The ligament's main function is to maintain anteversion of the uterus in the pelvic cavity. It is not affected during ovarian torsion.

C) INCORRECT:

The ovarian ligament is an embryonic remnant of the gubernaculum and connects the medial pole of the ovary to the uterine horns. It contains the ovarian branches of the uterine vessels, not the ovarian vessels themselves, and is not primarily affected by ovarian torsion.

D) INCORRECT:

The cardinal ligament connects the cervix to the lateral walls of the pelvis. It carries the uterine vessels and the ureter, not the ovarian vessels. Furthermore, the cardinal ligament is not affected during ovarian torsion.

E) CORRECT:

The suspensory ligament of the ovary (infundibulopelvic ligament) is a fold of peritoneum that connects the ovaries to the lateral walls of the pelvis. It carries the ovarian artery, vein, nerves, and lymphatics, and is affected during ovarian torsion, which requires surgical management. If the ovary is deemed nonviable, the infundibulopelvic ligament is ligated during oophorectomy. During this procedure, care must be taken not to damage the ureter, which is located directly posterior to the ligament in the retroperitoneum.
Image Description:

In ovarian torsion, the ovary twists around the adnexal ligaments, resulting in compression of the ovarian veins and lymphatics, consequently causing venous congestion and edema. The most important risk factor is ovarian enlargement, which can occur (e.g., due to ovarian cysts).
questions.hint: This patient's sudden onset of severe right flank pain, history of recurrent ovarian cysts, and lack of ovarian venous flow on Doppler are consistent with ovarian torsion.

questions.text: A 27-year-old pregnant woman reports sharp right groin pain aggravated by prolonged standing. Physical examination reveals tenderness near the superficial inguinal ring without a palpable mass. Which structure is most likely involved?
questions.solution:
A) INCORRECT:

The ovarian ligament connects the ovary to the uterus and remains within the pelvic cavity, not extending into the inguinal region. It does not traverse the inguinal canal, making it unlikely to cause tenderness near the superficial inguinal ring.

B) INCORRECT:

The uterosacral ligament extends from the cervix to the sacrum, supporting the uterus within the pelvis. It is associated with deep pelvic pain rather than groin pain near the superficial inguinal ring, as it does not traverse the inguinal canal.

C) INCORRECT:

The broad ligament is a peritoneal fold supporting the uterus within the pelvic cavity. It does not extend toward the inguinal region, making it unlikely to cause groin pain near the superficial inguinal ring.

D) CORRECT:

The round ligament of the uterus originates at the uterine horns and travels through the deep inguinal ring into the inguinal canal, terminating in the labia majora. During pregnancy, hormonal changes and increased uterine size can stretch the round ligament, causing pain, especially near the superficial inguinal ring. This anatomical course explains the sharp groin pain experienced by pregnant women, as the ligament is subjected to mechanical stress.

Key learning point: The round ligament of the uterus passes through the deep inguinal ring as it travels through the inguinal canal in females.

questions.text: A 28-year-old nulligravid woman presents to the gynecology clinic with a 6-month history of deep dyspareunia and difficulty conceiving. She describes sharp pelvic pain during intercourse, especially when supine. Her past medical history is unremarkable. On speculum examination, the cervix cannot be visualized. Bimanual palpation reveals the uterine fundus directed toward the sacral promontory and the cervix tilted posteriorly in the vaginal canal. Which of the following best describes this patient’s uterine position?
questions.solution:
A) INCORRECT:

With anteversion, the cervix points anteriorly relative to the vaginal canal, not posteriorly.

B) CORRECT:

Most commonly, the uterus is anteflexed by 120° (i.e., the uterine fundus points forward and the uterine body bends forward over the bladder) and anteverted by 90° (i.e., the cervix points anteriorly relative to the vaginal canal, rather than straight up or backward). However, other variants occur in 10% of women and may impair conception or cause dyspareunia. In this patient, the cervix is tilted posteriorly relative to the vaginal canal (retroverted), and the uterine body is also bent backward on the cervix such that the uterine fundus points toward the sacrum (retroflexed).

Key learning point: Version is the vagina-cervix angle, and flexion is the fundus-cervix angle.
Image Description:

The terms flexion and version are used to describe the position of the uterus.

Flexion refers to the angle between the axis of the uterine body (blue line) and the axis of the cervix (yellow line).
Version refers to the angle between the axis of the cervix and the axis of the vagina (green line).

The uterus is usually anteflexed by approx. 100° (AF) and anteverted by approx. 90° (AV), depending on how full the bladder is.

C) INCORRECT:

With anteversion, the cervix points anteriorly relative to the vaginal canal, not posteriorly. With anteflexion, the uterine fundus points forward, not posteriorly towards the sacrum.

D) INCORRECT:

With anteflexion, the uterine fundus points forward, not posteriorly towards the sacrum.
questions.hint: Flexion is the angle between the long axis of the uterine body (remember Fundus) and the long axis of the cervix in the sagittal plane. Version is the angle between the the long axis of the cervix and the long axis of the Vagina in the sagittal plane.

questions.text: You are seeing a 36-year-old woman in the emergency department with sudden-onset, severe right flank pain that began during her aerobics class. She denies any trauma. She has a history of recurrent ovarian cysts, and her menses are regular at 28-day intervals. Her temperature is 37.1°C. On abdominal examination, there is tenderness in the right lower quadrant with guarding. Pelvic ultrasound reveals a large simple cyst on the right ovary. Doppler shows detectable flow in the right ovarian artery, but no flow in the right ovarian vein. Which one of the following ligaments is most likely to have been involved?
questions.solution:
A) CORRECT:

The suspensory ligament of the ovary (infundibulopelvic ligament) is a fold of peritoneum that connects the ovaries to the lateral walls of the pelvis. It carries the ovarian artery, vein, nerves, and lymphatics, and is affected during ovarian torsion, which requires surgical management. If the ovary is deemed nonviable, the infundibulopelvic ligament is ligated during oophorectomy. During this procedure, care must be taken not to damage the ureter, which is located directly posterior to the ligament in the retroperitoneum.

Key learning point: The infundibulopelvic (suspensory) ligament contains the ovarian vessels and is the structure most commonly involved in ovarian torsion.
Image Description:

In ovarian torsion, the ovary twists around the adnexal ligaments, resulting in compression of the ovarian veins and lymphatics, consequently causing venous congestion and edema. The most important risk factor is ovarian enlargement, which can occur (e.g., due to ovarian cysts).

B) INCORRECT:

The round ligament of the uterus connects the labia majora to the uterine horns. It is a remnant of the gubernaculum and does not contain any vessels. The ligament's main function is to maintain anteversion of the uterus in the pelvic cavity. It is not affected during ovarian torsion.

C) INCORRECT:

The ovarian ligament is an embryonic remnant of the gubernaculum and connects the medial pole of the ovary to the uterine horns. It contains the ovarian branches of the uterine vessels, not the ovarian vessels themselves, and is not primarily affected by ovarian torsion.

D) INCORRECT:

The broad ligament is a fold of peritoneum that is divided into three parts: mesosalpinx, mesometrium, and mesovarium. It connects the lateral uterus, fallopian tubes, and ovaries with the lateral pelvic wall. Although it is in close relation to the ovaries, the ligament does not contain the ovarian vessels and is not primarily affected during ovarian torsion.

E) INCORRECT:

The cardinal ligament connects the cervix to the lateral walls of the pelvis. It carries the uterine vessels and the ureter, not the ovarian vessels. Furthermore, the cardinal ligament is not affected during ovarian torsion.
questions.hint: This patient's sudden onset of severe right flank pain, history of recurrent ovarian cysts, and lack of ovarian venous flow on Doppler are consistent with ovarian torsion.
